Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\), where \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) satisfy the coupled differential equations \\(\\dot{x} = ax - by\\) and \\(\\dot{y} = bx + ay\\), respectively, with constants a and b. Analyze the behavior of the function after applying the transformation \\( f(z) = e^{i\\omega t}z \\), where \\( \\omega \\) is a constant.

If a new function \\( g(z) = e^{i\\theta t}z \\) (where \\( \\theta \\) is another constant) is applied as an intervention at any time t_1, will the final state \\( z(T) \\) for T > t_1 be affected only by the constants a and b but not by \\( \\omega \\) and \\( \\theta \\)?
Explanation: The application of \\( g(z) \\) at \\( t_1 \\) introduces an additional phase rotation, thereby depending also on \\( \\theta \\) as well as \\( \\omega \\). Since these transformations influence the magnitude and phase of \\( z \\) throughout its evolution, the final state at t = T is not solely dependent on the original system constants a and b.
